description: This is a stout pole with a large steel flanged mace head on a short chain attached to it, based on the peasant flail agricultural tool except now with a metal head and made to thresh people in metal armor rather than grain.
This is a stout pole with a wooden club on a leather cord attached to it, this is a tool used to thresh wheat and occasionally people when the peasants got angry at their feudal lords.
A sturdy wood bat with a plastic handle.  Makes a great melee weapon.
An aluminum baseball bat with a plastic handle, lighter than a wooden bat and a little easier to swing as a result.
A baseball bat made out of foam rubber with a plastic handle.  Light and easy to wield, but almost completely ineffective.
A telescoping baton that collapses for easy storage.  Makes a good melee weapon.  Activate to expand.
A telescoping baton that collapses for easy storage.  Makes a good melee weapon.  Activate to collapse.
This is a huge axe designed for warfare.  Though intended for use as a weapon, it can also be pressed into service as a rather clumsy woodcutting tool.
This is a dull, cheaply made replica of a massive axe designed for warfare.
This is a huge axe designed for warfare.  You notice that the axe heads aren't seated properly at all.

This is a short, easily concealed bludgeoning weapon consisting of a weight embedded at the end of a short leather shaft.  Formerly used by law enforcement, this weapon is meant to stun or knock out the subject, although head strikes have a high risk of causing a permanent, disabling brain injury or being fatal.

This is a solid wood 'training' katana, exactingly crafted to mimic the weight and balance of the real thing.  Despite its lack of a sharp metal edge, it's still quite capable of inflicting deadly wounds.
//: MA reference I used held that a bokken crushes rather than cuts (or impales) but is otherwise just as damaging as a katana.  Nerfed by popular demand.

description: This is a solid wood 'training' katana, but feels far too light to make an effective weapon.
//: This is a stopgap measure because defining cutting as 0 using proportional gave the test a fit.

description: This is a solid wood 'training' katana, but it looks to be mass-produced, and not quite as effective as the real deal.
//: This is a stopgap measure because defining cutting as 0 using proportional gave the test a fit.

description: An improvised weapon, made from two spikes attached to a bowling pin in the shape of a 'T'.
A blunt bowling pin.  Makes a decent melee weapon, if somewhat short.
A baseball bat wrapped with barbed wire.  A brutal melee weapon.
Handicapped or not, you always walk in style.  Consisting of a metal headpiece and a wooden body, this makes a great bashing weapon in a pinch.
A sinister looking cane made of plastic.  It has a shiny red orb gripped by claws at the handle.
An arcane but cheap looking cane made of plastic.  It has a white, light-up orb at the handle.  Using it will turn it on and provide some minor light.

use_action.msg: You turn the wizard cane on.
use_action.need_charges_msg: The wizard cane's batteries are dead.

use_action.msg: You turn the wizard cane off.

description: An arcane looking cane made of wood and aluminum.  It has a white, light-up orb at the handle.  Using it will turn it on and illuminate the area around you.

use_action.msg: You turn the wizard cane on.
use_action.need_charges_msg: The wizard cane's batteries are dead.

use_action.msg: You turn the wizard cane off.

description: An improvised cane.  It also works as a basic bashing weapon in a pinch.
This is little more than a plank of wood, snapped in half and with a crude handle whittled into one end.  It looks similar to a poorly-made cricket bat.
This is little more than a long plank of wood with a crude handle whittled into one end.  It's too big to be called a club.  Massive, thick, heavy, and far too rough.
A pair of crutches.
A pair of wooden makeshift crutches.
A slender long rod of wood, while traditionally intended as a training tool for many dueling moves, it still makes a good melee weapon in a pinch.

//: Id retained to avoid breaking anything, same reason as with the makeshift glaive.
description: A flat wooden club with sharpened pieces of stone sticking to both of its sides.
A glass shard with wrapping at one end so it can be safely wielded.
A long handle with a big metal head, flat on one side, for driving golf balls.  Fore!
A large, heavy hammer.  Makes an acceptable melee weapon for the very strong, but is nearly useless in the hands of the weak.
A shorter sledge hammer, still as weighty, however, due to the same steel head.  Worse as a melee weapon but is a more portable tool.
A stout and hefty hammer, more akin to a sledge than a typical ball-peen.  Useful for portable demolition work, but is very unwieldy as a weapon.
A large sledge hammer with a massive, heavy head.  This unwieldy tool is meant to break concrete, rock, brick, anything really.
A curved wooden stick with a wide and flat end.  Commonly used by hockey players.
A long piece of wood with several chunks of steel firmly tied to it.  The resulting weapon is unwieldy and slow but very heavy hitting.
A long wooden staff, which has been reinforced with metal bands and caps.

Produced by the Light corporation, this stylish staff not only functions as a light source, but doubles as a light-weight weapon, due to the superalloy materials it is made of.  Due to proprietary efficiency improvements over standard light sources, the L-stick or light stick as it is commonly called, batteries last longer than other light sources.

Produced by the Light corporation, this stylish staff not only functions as a light source, but doubles as a light-weight weapon, due to the superalloy materials it is made of.  Due to proprietary efficiency improvements over standard light sources, the L-stick or light stick as it is commonly called, batteries last longer than other light sources.  The staff is glowing brightly, which is slowly draining the batteries.
This is a versatile polearm with a spiked hammer head, a spike, and a hook attached to a beefy wooden pole.
This is a cheap piece of crap imitation of a versatile polearm with a spiked hammer head, probably meant to be used for LARPing.
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy metal end.  It is heavy and slow, but its crushing damage is devastating.
//: Same total damage and slightly higher weight than a morningstar - exchanged.

description: A light, cheaply made replica of a medieval weapon that would normally consist of a wood handle with a heavy metal end.
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy metal end.  That metal end feels a bit loose.
A stick with a circular lump of metal tied to it masquerading as a mace.  You could probably improve it by finding a way to pin the head to the handle.
A mace made from a circular chunk of steel pinned to the end of a stick.  You can feel your inner Trench Raider come alive when you wield it.
A pipe with a handful of pipe fittings screwed onto the end to give it a weighty head for bashing.
Two pipes fitted end-to-end with more pipe fittings screwed onto the far end.  The result is a large, but awkward bludgeon.
Three pipes fitted end-to-end in a monstrously heavy facsimile of a quarterstaff.
While nothing more than a bronze sphere on a stick, it is still surprisingly effective.
This is an improvised sap, also known as a cosh, slapjack and slapper.  A short and flat bludgeoning weapon consisting of a weight embedded between two patches of leather.

A large hammer, forged from the heart of a dying star.  It bears the inscription:

Whosoever holds this hammer,
If he be worthy,
Shall possess the power to…
CRUSH!'
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.  It deals devastating crushing damage, with a small amount of piercing to boot.
A light, cheaply made replica of a medieval weapon that would normally consist of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.
A light, cheaply made replica of a medieval weapon that would normally consist of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.
A baseball bat with several nails driven through it, an excellent melee weapon.
A plank of wood with several nails through one end; essentially a simple mace.  Makes an acceptable melee weapon.
A hard-wood stick designed for hitting colorful balls around a felt table.  Truly, the coolest of sports.
The Monadnock PR-24 baton is a collapsible, lightweight, side-handle baton used by law enforcement all over the world.  The PR designation is rumored to mean Public Relations.  Activate to retract.
The Monadnock PR-24 baton is a collapsible, lightweight, side-handle baton used by law enforcement all over the world.  The PR designation is rumored to mean Public Relations.  Activate to extend.

use_action.msg: You snap open your PR-24 baton.

description: A sturdy staff carved out of wood.  Lightweight and long, it is surprisingly easy to handle.
A wooden staff weapon used in Okinawan martial arts.  Finely sanded and treated with oil for integrity.
A pair of nested socks filled with a stone.  A true weapon of despair.
An oblong plastic trinket with the far end ground down into a stabbing point.

A stout knotty stick with a large knob at the top that has been left to cure in a chimney.  A traditional Irish weapon, the shillelagh was originally used for settling disputes in a gentlemanly manner.

A stout knotty stick with a large knob at the top that has been left to cure in a chimney.  A traditional Irish weapon, the shillelagh was originally used for settling disputes in a gentlemanly manner.  The knob has been hollowed and filled with molten heavy metal to pack more of a punch.
A fake shillelagh massproduced as a souvenir for tourists.  This knotty stick has not been cured in a chimney like a traditional shillelagh but has had fake black soot painted on.

This is an ironshod quarterstaff that has a high-voltage stun gun built into the handle.  The stun gun is wired to the metal caps at either end of the staff, allowing you to zap a dangerous opponent should beating them senseless with it prove too hazardous.

This is a reinforced plastic tonfa; the core is hollowed out and is filled with capacitors and a high-yield rechargeable storage battery.  When a switch on the handle is pressed, a high-voltage current is transmitted to the two electrodes mounted in the end of the tonfa, and by extension to anyone unfortunate enough to be in contact with them.  It also has a nifty flashlight, which is off at the moment.

This is a reinforced plastic tonfa; the core is hollowed out and is filled with capacitors and a high-yield rechargeable storage battery.  When a switch on the handle is pressed, a high-voltage current is transmitted to the two electrodes mounted in the end of the weapon, and by extension to anyone unfortunate enough to be in contact with them.  The integral flashlight is turned on, continually draining power and lighting the surrounding area.
A hard plastic truncheon commonly employed by police.  Originally an Okinawan weapon, it consists of a stick with a perpendicular handle attached a third of the way down its length.
A stout wooden truncheon of the sort commonly employed by police.  Originally an Okinawan weapon, it consists of a stick with a perpendicular handle attached a third of the way down its length.
A medieval hammer with a spike on one end made for battle.  Its odd shape and balance make it an excellent weapon, but an ineffective tool.
//: Craftable from steel, shouldn't be silver.  A warhammer is essentially one end of a pickaxe with balancing weight on the other and crushes/pierces the armor.
